Agent.text: Hello. Don't see too many travellers out these parts.
Agent.Speaker: demo100cr_barkeep
Agent.Comment:
Using a plot flag condition/action like this has the same effect as setting line visibility to "only show line once per game", but has the added benefit of allowing other scripts and conversations to know whether it's been encountered. 

In this case, when the player encounters the bandit who's taken over the Blue Moon Inn his dialogue will be able to refer to the DEMO_TALKED_TO_BARKEEP plot flag to  take into account whether the player knows he's not an actual innkeeper.

Agent.text: It is, but you don't want to go in there.
Agent.Speaker: demo100cr_barkeep

Agent.text: I am minding my business. Well, trying to.
Agent.Speaker: demo100cr_barkeep

Agent.text: Got kicked out of my own inn by some bandits!
Agent.Speaker: demo100cr_barkeep
Agent.Comment:
Use "Copy" and then "Paste as link" to link multiple branches of a conversation to the same node, as is done with this one.

This allows a variety of effects that a simple tree-based structure on its own can't handle. Multiple branches of a conversation can converge back together, conversations can jump to entirely different branches, and so forth.

Agent.text: Well... not to get the inn back, anyway.
Agent.Speaker: demo100cr_barkeep

Agent.text: Nothing. I don't want that ruddy inn back.
Agent.Speaker: demo100cr_barkeep

Agent.text: I used to be an adventurer, you see, and I've been thinking I'd like to get back on the road again.
Agent.Speaker: demo100cr_barkeep
Agent.Comment:
Use "Copy" and then "Paste as link" to link multiple branches of a conversation to the same node, as is done with this one.

This allows a variety of effects that a simple tree-based structure on its own can't handle. Multiple branches of a conversation can converge back together, conversations can jump to entirely different branches, and so forth.

Agent.text: But I'll need my trusty sword to do that, and it's still in the inn. I could reward you to retrieve it.
Agent.Speaker: demo100cr_barkeep

Agent.text: Excellent! It's stored in the kitchen, in a chest. Here's the key.
Agent.Speaker: demo100cr_barkeep
Agent.Comment:
When the flag DEMO_QUEST_ACCEPTED is set an event is sent to the plot's script, which handles inserting the key into the player's inventory. See the demo000pl_main script for details. Note that it's not strictly necessary to put the key in the player's inventory at this particular point in time, the notification of having recieved an item won't happen until the conversation is over anyway.

Another feature of note on this line; it's linked to from the "Have you reconsidered my request?" branch of the conversation. In this way we can centralize the quest-acceptance dialogue and associated plot flags, making it easier to write and less likely to have errors.

To find what other nodes of the conversation link to a given line, if any, right-click on the line and select "find links" from the dropdown menu.

Finally, if you click on the "Animation" tab and then select either OWNER or PLAYER in the "Tag" dropdown menu, you'll see that instead of the randomly-generated conversation gestures the two actors have been manually set with animations to make it seem like a key is physically changing hands. The "Lock Tag" checkbox is checked, meaning that if you automatically generate new gestures for the conversation these particular actors in this particular conversation node won't get new gestures generated for them.

Agent.text: But there's a catch. My main security system actually isn't the lock on the chest. I put a small barrel in front of the door as well.
Agent.Speaker: demo100cr_barkeep

Agent.text: Hey, it works. Don't knock it. Anyway, the only way to remove the barrel is to pull the lever in the back of the main room, at the top of the flight of stairs.
Agent.Speaker: demo100cr_barkeep
Agent.Comment:
Use "Copy" and then "Paste as link" to link multiple branches of a conversation to the same node, as is done with this one.

This allows a variety of effects that a simple tree-based structure on its own can't handle. Multiple branches of a conversation can converge back together, conversations can jump to entirely different branches, and so forth.

In this case two player responses lead to exactly the same line. This may seem like a superfluous waste, but it's generally good game design to give the player a choice every once in a while - even if it's only the illusion of a choice.

Agent.text: Good luck. I'll be waiting here with your reward.
Agent.Speaker: demo100cr_barkeep

Agent.text: Well, suit yourself, I suppose.
Agent.Speaker: demo100cr_barkeep
Agent.Comment:
Use "Copy" and then "Paste as link" to link multiple branches of a conversation to the same node, as is done with this one.

This allows a variety of effects that a simple tree-based structure on its own can't handle. Multiple branches of a conversation can converge back together, conversations can jump to entirely different branches, and so forth.

Agent.text: Indeed.
Agent.Speaker: demo100cr_barkeep

Agent.text: Have you reconsidered my request?
Agent.Speaker: demo100cr_barkeep
Agent.Comment:
If the player spoke with the innkeeper but declined his quest, DEMO_TALKED_TO_BARKEEP is true and DEMO_QUEST_ACCEPTED is false. This branch of the conversation gives the player a "second chance" to reconsider and accept the quest, and remains as the default line for as long as the player continues to decline it.

If you encounter a more complex situation that needs to be distilled down into a single true/false conditional like this, consider using a "defined" plot flag like DEMO_DECLINED_QUEST (see the plot file and associated event script for this example).

Agent.text: My sword's still in there. I'm not budging from this spot one way or the other until I get it back.
Agent.Speaker: demo100cr_barkeep
Agent.Comment: This is an ambient line that plays when the player clicks on the barkeep before returning his sword. Ambient lines are played without going into conversation mode - the character will simply speak it out loud, and the player is free to move around or ignore it without interruption in gameplay.

Agent.text: Ah, my sword! Wonderful!
Agent.Speaker: demo100cr_barkeep
Agent.Comment: This condition/action pair is similar to the one with DEMO_TALKED_TO_BARKEEP at the beginning of the first branch of this conversation. However, in this case the plot event script performs an action when DEMO_SWORD_RETURNED is set; it removes the sword from the player's inventory and opens up an area on the world map.

Agent.text: And now your reward. As I said, I want to take up adventuring. I can be your henchman now!
Agent.Speaker: demo100cr_barkeep

Agent.text: Never mind that I got beaten up by a bandit that turned out to be easy to kill. Do you want me to come along?
Agent.Speaker: demo100cr_barkeep

Agent.text: Great! Just lead the way.
Agent.Speaker: demo100cr_barkeep

Agent.text: Oh. Well... okay, then. I'll go have a solo adventure of my own. Maybe kill a few Archdemons.
Agent.Speaker: demo100cr_barkeep

Agent.text: The demo's over, I don't have more to say.
Agent.Speaker: demo100cr_barkeep
Agent.Comment: You should always have a line at the end of a conversation with no conditional check on it, like this one. That way no matter what happens the character will always have a "default" line to fall back on. If no conversation lines are able to fire, clicking on the character will generate no response.

Agent.text: 0`investigate`Need some info.`Is this the Blue Moon Inn?
Agent.Speaker: PLAYER
Agent.Comment: Blue lines are responses that the player can give. Red lines are spoken by non-player creatures or objects. Multiple blue lines can be displayed when the conversation reaches their parent node, but only the first playable red line will be given when there are multiple options.

Agent.text: 1`mad`Don't bother me.`Mind your business.
Agent.Speaker: PLAYER

Agent.text: 0`investigate`Can I help?`Oh, do you need any help?
Agent.Speaker: PLAYER

Agent.text: 2`payment`Can do it for a fee`Hm. How much would you pay for me to clear them out?
Agent.Speaker: PLAYER

Agent.text: 1`yes`Sure!`Okay.
Agent.Speaker: PLAYER

Agent.text: 2`confused`What?`How can that stop anyone?
Agent.Speaker: PLAYER

Agent.text: 0`pleased`Ha, funny!`That's silly.
Agent.Speaker: PLAYER

Agent.text: 4`no`No!`Not interested.
Agent.Speaker: PLAYER
PLAYER
Agent.Comment: The player hasn't accepted the quest. We don't set any flags here to keep track of that fact, but see the section on the DEMO_DECLINED_QUEST plot flag in the main plot's event script to see how "defined" plot flags work and how they can be used to check for things like this.

Agent.text: 2`stoic`Life is hard.`Yeah, times are rough out here.
Agent.Speaker: PLAYER

Agent.text: 1`yes`I'll help you`Yes, I'll get your sword back for you.
Agent.Speaker: PLAYER
Agent.Comment: The next line in this conversation jumps back into the previous main branch of dialogue, allowing the reuse of the "quest acceptance" lines that the player avoided previously.

Agent.text: 4`no`Not Interested...`Yes, and I'm still not interested.
Agent.Speaker: PLAYER

Agent.text: 1`pleased`Absolutelly!`Sure, the more, the merrier.
Agent.Speaker: PLAYER
PLAYER
Agent.Comment: This triggers the code for causing the barkeep to join your party as a henchman. See the plot event script for detail.

Agent.text: 2`sad`Not a chance!`No, I don't think so.
Agent.Speaker: PLAYER
Agent.Comment: Note that if the player declines the barkeep's offer of henchmanship there's no way for the player to change his mind later, unlike the situation when deciding whether to accept the quest to recover the sword.
